title: The Ghost File: A chmod 000 Story
scenario: A developer tries to 'secure' their password file by removing all permissions with chmod 000. They soon discover why this is a terrible idea.

timeline.description: File permissions changed to --------- (nobody can access it)
Developer tries to read file: 'cat passwords.txt' → Permission denied
Developer tries to edit file: 'nano passwords.txt' → Permission denied
Developer tries to delete file: 'rm passwords.txt' → Permission denied (can't even delete it!)
Developer realizes: 'I locked myself out of my own file!'
Developer tries: 'sudo cat passwords.txt' → Success! (root can still access it)
Developer fixes it: 'sudo chmod 600 passwords.txt' (owner can read/write)
Developer learns: chmod 000 doesn't protect files, it just locks everyone out (including you)

outcome: The file became a 'ghost file' - visible in directory listings but completely inaccessible. Even the owner couldn't read, write, or delete it without sudo. chmod 000 is not security, it's self-sabotage.
lessons_learned: chmod 000 locks EVERYONE out, including the file owner
Root/sudo can still access 000 files, so it's not real security
For read-only files, use chmod 400 (owner can read)
For private files, use chmod 600 (owner can read and write)
Real security comes from encryption, not permission tricks
If you accidentally chmod 000, use 'sudo chmod' to fix it
